content.title: Hypothermic Circulatory Arrest in Aortic Surgery
content.description: Deep hypothermia with circulatory arrest used to protect the brain and spinal cord during complex aortic arch and thoracoabdominal aortic surgery.
content.definition: Hypothermic circulatory arrest (HCA) involves cooling the body to 14-28°C to reduce metabolic demands, allowing brief periods of circulatory arrest for open aortic arch surgery. May be combined with selective antegrade or retrograde cerebral perfusion.

temperature_strategies: Deep hypothermia (14-20°C): Safe arrest time ~40 minutes
Moderate hypothermia (20-28°C): Requires cerebral perfusion adjuncts
Goal: Reduce cellular metabolic demand during no-flow state
cerebral_protection: Antegrade cerebral perfusion (ACP): Via innominate or axillary artery
Retrograde cerebral perfusion (RCP): Via SVC, less effective
Unilateral ACP: Right hemisphere + circle of Willis
management_details: Cardiopulmonary bypass for cooling and rewarming
Arrest time depends on temperature and perfusion strategy
Rewarming gradual to avoid neurologic injury

learning_objectives: Recognize safe circulatory arrest times by temperature
Apply HCA for appropriate aortic pathology
clinical_pearls: At 18°C, safe arrest time is ~30-40 minutes without perfusion
Antegrade cerebral perfusion extends safe arrest time significantly
pH-stat vs alpha-stat blood gas management remains debated
Bilateral ACP is preferred when anatomy allows
Coagulopathy is major complication - have blood products ready
